div.div: On each node (regardless of dummy vs data) ,

ul.li: There is a list ver interval for which the node is traversable.
The lo incl bound == curr_list_ver at the time the node was swapped-in.
The hi incl bound == (curr_list_ver-1) at the time the node was replaced away.

switch.text: On each node (regardless of dummy vs data) ,...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 478px; height: 1px; padding-top: 2567px; margin-left: 2002px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.span: When a txn unholds a list_ver `x` :

ol.li:
held_list_vers
[ x ] -= 1; and if count became zero, remove entry.

Search in
held_list_vers
, and get x's directly lower and higher still-held vers. This is a newly gc'able interval.

li.span: If there is a newly gc'able interval :

div.div: Big-O cost of work under mutex guard =

switch.text: When a txn unholds a list_ver `x` :...

ol.li:
The list_ver interval for which this node is traversable is
[ node.traversable_list_ver_lo_incl ~
curr_list_ver
).

Search in
held_list_vers
to see if this interval is deletable now.

li.span: For node in deletable_nodes : delete nodes from disk and from memory.
For node in new_dangling_nodes : insert into

div.div: Big-O cost of work under mutex guard =
If we try to delete immediately :

div.span: (number of nodes in the replaced slice) *

ol.li:
Record the node's lo bound as
curr_list_ver
.
(This info is recorded in memory only, not on disk; so it doesn't incur any big cost.)

div.div: Big-O cost of work under mutex guard =

for any intervals that are subsumed by the just-received deletable interval.

div.div: The channel can be limited in capacity. If full, incoming messages should drop existing messages. Eventually, a later message will subsume dropped messages' intervals.

g.text: Local variables of the F+C job

div.div:
dangling_nodes
: BTreeMap or HashMap of
(key) Interval< ListVer >
== the ListVer interval in which the associated nodes are traversable.
(value) Vec< Node >

div.div: These operations update or push a dummy at the head:

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 438px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1567px; margin-left: 362px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

ul.li: We want to store hold_count on dummies only, so that F+C is not prevented from replacing nodes holding persisted data.
Performance. Prevent O(n) re-traversal from the head, when eventually ready to replace or insert. (See the separate doc diagram on concurrent LL modification.)

li.span: If a dummy exists, its hold_count += 1.

ul.li: If a dummy exists, do not update it.

div.div:
All of these operations:
With exclusive
lock
:
head :=
head_ptr
.load();
If head is a dummy :
Modify it.
Else :
d := new dummy;
d.older = head;
head_ptr
.store( d );
Big-O cost of work under mutex guard =
O(1)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 2667px; margin-left: 610px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;

display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 478px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1047px; margin-left: 42px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Consequences of doing these opers non-atomically:
By the time a thread holds snap_commit_ver_hi_excl=x, the boundary between (x-1 <--> x) might already have been erased.
Hence, conflict-checking yields false-conflicts at a higher probability. Conflict-checking is guaranteed not to over-check (i.e. encroach into x-1 and lower versions) iff there are zero concurrent commitments --- this defeats the main advantage of SSI cf. serial execution.
Possible enforcement of correctness:
Retry the transaction.
Should the group be atomic?:
Yes.

switch.text: Consequences of doing these opers non-atomically:...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 478px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1047px; margin-left: 562px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.b: Consequences of doing these opers non-atomically:
div.span:
By the time a thread holds list_ver=x, x might already have been erased.
A "held list ver" is guaranteed to be smaller-than-or-eq-to the actually traversed list ver. Hence, a "held list ver" can be interpreted only as a "minimum possibly held list ver". And, the "global minimum" can jump backwards.
div.div: {Each thread traverses the LL strictly after holding} and {GC deletes from lower to higher list vers, less than the currently known "globally minimum possibly held list ver"}.

Possibly no.
But likely yes we want atomic.

switch.text: Consequences of doing these opers non-atomically:...

g.text: Conceptual registers, and atomic operations on them

box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Feasibly correct.
Txn sees P=x, and defines its initial snapshot as ( -inf ~ x ].
It traverses over but ignores the node with commit_ver=x+1.
Txn sees P = x' > x; and changes its snapshot to [ x+1 ~ x' ].
This time it does not ignore the node with commit_ver=x+1.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 468px; height: 1px; padding-top: 840px; margin-left: 2652px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

ol.li:
Txn sees P=x+1, and defines its initial snapshot as ( -inf ~ x+1 ].
But it does not traverse over a node with commit_ver=x+1.

If the txn is not read-only, it must eventually read commit_ver=x+1.
To do so, it must spin-wait on the head pointer, until nodes with commit_ver>=x+1 are pushed.
Also, it must not unhold the snapshot's list_ver; or else the commit_ver boundary (x <--> x+1) might disappear.

Txn refreshes P and sees P=x' > x+1.
It migt have to repeat the above step (spin-wait) indefinitely.

div.div: There are too many edge cases.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 396px; height: 1px; padding-top: 665px; margin-left: 2303px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Let T := the newest commit_ver that is traversable.
Let P := the posted max_commit_ver info (i.e. next_commit_ver - 1).

switch.text: Let T := the newest commit_ver that is traversable....

display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Feasibly correct.
GC must delete from lower to higher list vers, less than the currently known "globally minimum possibly held list ver".
Txn sees P=x, and holds list_ver=x as being in use.
It actually never traverses over nodes which became dangling as of list_ver=x+1, but nevertheless prevents these nodes from being garbage-collected.
Txn un-holds list_ver=x.
Now those said nodes can be garbage-collected. There is delay, but no incorrectness.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 468px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1240px; margin-left: 2652px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Incorrect.
Txn sees P=x+1, and holds list_ver=x+1 as being in use.
Meanwhile, it traverses over list version x, over nodes that will become dangling as of list_ver=x+1.
F+C replaces a slice, leaving the traversable list in version x+1.
Garbage collector deletes dangling nodes that became dangling as of list_ver=x+1.
Txn may be still reading them! Use-after-free!

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 398px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1065px; margin-left: 2302px;

display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Let T := the logical list_ver associated with the currently traversable list.
Let P := the posted curr_list_ver info.

switch.text: Let T := the logical list_ver associated with the currently traver...

Merge non-held commit_vers
